Shirley Chisholm, the first black congresswoman in
America, represents a New York district which includes
Bedford-Stuyesant, one of the nation's largest ghettoes.
The 52-year-old Chisholm became a national political
figure in 1972 when she made a presidential bid and

Election Results
Homewood (Special)--After a tense three-day flurry at
campus polls, the Hopkins Tabulations Headquarters
announced Wednesday night the winners in the annual
Student Council elections. An unusually large turnout for
the voting—almost one-half the student body—was
variously attributed to the warm weather, the concern
over administration maneuverings, and the mistaking of
ballot boxes for kleenex dispensers.
In the Presidential race, a five-person struggle was pared
to a two-man runoff. Stu Davidson, a sophomore who has
been characterized as "an intellectual Ralph Kramden,"
moved one step closer to "the big time, Alice!", as did
Junior David Chesanow. The latter, however, faces almost
a two-hundred vote deficit to be made up in the finals
(trailing Davidson in the preliminaries, 382 to 193).
Left in the canipaign lurch were Brad Stark, Gary
Stahl, and Bunny Howard. The two remaining candidates
may have to barter for their important blocs of votes to
gain the top spot, as primary losers can often spell trouble
for the victors (cf. Ronald Reagan, How to Leave Your
OPponent Thirty Points Down on Some Godforsaken Ski
Slope).
The Vice-Presidential contest came down to the wire,
as Randy Randazzo edged out the other half of the
Chesanow ticket, Andy Albstein, 401-380. Promotional
agents for Fleetwood Mac, Dave Mason, and Jackie Wilson
are standing by. Pat Gatling became the new Student
•Council Secretary, swamping her opponent Bryan Stamm
524-172.
For the final position in the yearly SC quartet, one
contendor was eliminated and the other two slated for a
run-off next week. The odd man o it was Dave Lewing
(by a ,mere eight votes), who was immediately claimed on
waivers by the Toronto Blue Jays, Hopkins' parent team.
Meanwhile, primary leader Val Fein (320 votes) and
rwiner-up Neal Pilzer (244) gird themselves for another
grueling campaign week, like their Presidential
counterparts. Outgoing two-term Treasurer Ron Bialek
Plans to retire to La Crosse, Wisconsin, where he will
supervise the activities of the Police Athletic League and
handle the women's sports desk for the La Crosse Check.
While this week's election fervor died down, a related
Political incident heated up Wednesday afternoon. A
sizable crowd (estimated in the thirties) gathered in front
of Homewood House to protest the decision by the
Committee on Undergraduate Studies to drop the present
credited form of Intersession.
The protestors, served Schaefer beer by the Protest
Social Committee, found only two of their number
allowed to enter Homewood House to talk to the Deans.
The pair—Andy Davis and Sheldon Himmelfarb—entered
the administrative enclave as the demonstrators kept an
angry vigil outdoors. They returned a short time later,
armed with mimeographed statements drawn up by Dean
Suskind and approved by Dean Owen.
The double-Dean, memo listed three points (in all
capital letters): that the Dean's Office didn't particularly
care what happened to Intersesion, that it was the CUS
board--a faculty organization--that had made the decision,
and that students should address their grievances to and
haggle with faculty members, not the Dean of the Faculty
of Arts and Sciences or the Dean of Undergraduate and
Graduate Studies, who should be left pleasantly alone in
the renovating Homewood House.
With the release of the statement, the crowd quickly
dispersed. Students walked away wondering where to
carry the protest next, and probably mulling over to
Whom the burden would be passed that night. Such a
decision will be made this coming week.

By RUSS SMITH
Washington, D.0
"We're getting to the end of our rope. We've
cooperated with the FBI, we've kept from publicly
criticizing the FBI, but we're not further along in the
investigation now than we were six months ago."-Michael
Moffitt
Michael Moffitt is an angry young man and there's a
good reason why. It's been over six months now since
Moffitt's wife Ronni and former Chilean ambassador
Orlando Letelier were assassinated on Washington's
Embassy Row. Over six months and still the FBI has
failed to capture their killers.
And it's not as if the FBI is short on leads. In fact,
Moffitt and his co-workers at the Institute for Policy
Studies [IPS] have provided investigators with the names
and addresses of the men they say planted the bomb in
Letelier's car last September.
"We have evidence that the assassination was ordered
by DINA [Chile's secret police] and carried out by six
Cuban ex`iles, all veteran terrorists, who are now living in
Florida," claims Moffitt. The FBI has been given this
information but refuses to act on it, looking instead for
non-political motives for the killings. The most frustrating
part, says Moffitt, is that the FBI knows that IPS is right
but still won't do anything.
A possible key link in the case is Orlando Bosch, a
terrorist with DINA affiliations, who is now in jail in
Venezuela. Moffitt believes that Bosch could let go with
some valuable talk if only the FBI would make the effort.
"We've been told time and time again that they're
ready to move on the case, and now they say they're
stymied. Does someone else have to get their head blown
off to show the FBI that DINA isn't kidding around?"
Moffitt commented. Failing immediate action from the
FBI, IPS may call for a special congressional investigation
into the murders, although considering Congress' track
record on that score, not many are optimistic about the
results of such an investigation.
"This assassination is a direct outgrowth of U.S. foreign

policy since World War II. The CIA has been trying to
destroy progressive movements in Third World countries
committed to social change for years now," Moffitt said.
The people of Chile join those of Iran, Brazil, Vietnam
and a host of other countries who have been savagely
victimized by American imperialism since World War II.
It's no secret that a public airing of this murder probe
would do little to bolster the flagging image of the CIA
mainly because of its close ties with DINA and other
foreign secret police netwprds. Exactly what the Cia role
in the Letelier assassination is remains unclear, but
according to Moffitt, "It's inconceivable that foreign
police are carrying out illegal activities in the United
States without the CIA knowing about them." It's also no
secret that the Cuban gunmen were CIA-trained. So, it's
not hard to figure out why the FBI is dragging its feet on
the investigation.
And there's no indication that this terrorism will stop.
"A person I know is said to be on DINA's hit list, he's
been harrassed and followed, but we still can't get police
protection for him or any other Chilean," stated Moffitt.
Relations between the United States and Chile are
bound to be less friendly during Jimmy Carter's
administration, but whether the Chilean Junta is given a
wrist-slapping or is dealt with morel severely remains to be
seen. Moffitt's unsure about Carter's position , saying
"It's another case of him promising something during the
campaign and not knowing whether he'll act on it."
Moffitt added that the Chilean government was
disappointed when Carter nosed out Ford last November
because they think he's "too dangerous" and "too far to
the left."
Meanwhile, DINA agents are busier than ever, stalking
around Washington,. checking out campuses, tracking

students played cards, chess, smoked (cigarettes), drank
beer, and sang German and Latin songs led by the
classicist Basil Gildersleeve. Later the group established a
regular meeting hall in the back room of a grocery store.
Saint Dennis, a black man, tended the fire and
occasionally crossed the street to buy refreshments for the
students. In ten years the kneipe gave way to a more
organized Johns Hopkins University Club with Professor
Gildersleeve presiding. Unfortunately undergraduates
were screwed again as membership was limited to those
twenty-five and over. Thus, many students had to seek
thrills elsewhere.
The first society formed solely in the interests of the
undergraduates was the Matriculate Society. Their
opening dance--or "hop", as it was appropriately
called —was held on Commemoration Day, 1887, in the
gymnasium. Due to its success, the hops were held on
other occasions. Despite the fact that Goucher College
allowed only girls living with their parents to attend the
hops, there were usually enough "locals" on hand to
dance with.

was donated to the Athletic Association.
The first Glee Club was formed in 1879 and enjoyed a
very short life. In 1883 another Glee Club was organized,
with tenor Woodrow Wilson among its first members. But
a banjo and mandolin club formed five years later was so
'popular that it knocked the Glee Club out of prominence.

performed concerts in Maryland and other states. Several
students, perhaps realizing their true talents, never

abruptly stop at Hopkins. Is wasn't until almost the end

In 1897 a music appreciation club was formed.
Concerts were performed in the original McCoy Hall
downtown, under the direction of the Peabody
Conservatory of Music. In a few years interest in this
music association waned.

Long John's will probably seem unfamiliar to the seasoned local barg..,er, what with its higher-class
interior and close surroundings. Like any good bar, however, a few rounds and words with the regulars will

afternoon, a pack of Blue Jay stickmen warmed up for

Henry
Ciccarone, "play a gambling style of lacrosse that

season."

tremendous rush and it looked as though Hobart would

Parkway.
